p:
Thyme EO completely inhibited tick oviposition at 100% at a concentration of 1.562 μl/ml whereas the other EO induced this same effect at greater concentrations ranging from 3.125 to 6.25 μl/ml ( Table 2). At the same concentration (1.562 μl/ml), thyme EO completely inhibited reproduction of H. scupense. This concentration is significantly lower than what was recorded with the other EO (3.125 - 6.25 μl/ml). The eclosion rates of the eggs in all treatments were significantly different as compared to controls (p < 0.05). Note that thyme and rosemary EO are more inhibitors of eclosion than other EO such as those of river red gum and blue gum. At 24 hours, thyme EO proved to be the most larvicidal, whereas the least larvicidal was blue gum EO. On the 6th day, the most and the least larvicidal EO remained the same as those obtained in 24 h ( Table 3, Figures 1
– 6). We observed no mortality in control groups in LIT and AIT.
